case_name: Tata Iron and Steel Company Ltd. v. Abdul Gani

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 286 of 1960 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 286 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Patna High Court judgment and decree dated March 26, 1958 in Second Appeal No. 1330 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 26, 1958, of the Patna High Court in Second Appeal No. 1330 of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 9, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. November 9. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA, J.-

facts.text: Subject-matter is plot of land measuring 1267 sq. ft. in Sakchi New Planning area in Jamshedpur.

anchor.surface_text: The subject-matter of this litigation is a plot of land measuring 1267 sq. ft. in the Sakchi New Planning area in the town of Jamshedpur.

facts.text: On June 23, 1937, Abdul Gani applied for settlement of the plot to Land Officer of Tata Iron and Steel Company Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: On June 23,1937, Abdul Gani, through whom the present appellant claims to be interested in the land, applied for settlement of this plot of land to the Land Officer of the owner of the land, the Tata Iron and Steel Company Ltd.

facts.text: Application allowed and land let out to Abdul Gani as month to month tenant at Re. 1 per month.

anchor.surface_text: The application was allowed and the land was let out to Abdul Gani as a tenant from month to month at a rent of Re. 1/per month.

facts.text: Suit brought in 1949 for ejectment after notice to quit and arrears of rent at Re 1 per month.

anchor.surface_text: The suit out of which this appeal has arisen was brought in 1949 for ejectment of the tenant after determination of the tenancy by a numberice to quit the premises. There was also, a prayer for arrears of rent at Re 1/- per month.

facts.text: Abdul Gani defended claiming to be agriculturist tenant under Chotanagpur Tenancy Act and not a monthly tenant.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of Abdul Gani was that he was an agriculturist tenant as companytemplated under the Ghotanagpur Tenancy Act and number a monthly tenant and that numbermonthly rent was paid for the land

facts.text: Defendant pleaded lease for agricultural and horticultural purposes at annual rent acquiring occupancy right not liable to ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: It was, also pleaded that the lease being for agricultural and horticultural purposes at an annual rent, the defendant acquired a valid occupancy right and was number liable to ejectment.

facts.text: Present appellant added as defendant by order dated May 25, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The present appellant was added as a defendant by an order dated May 25, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant filed written statement contending Abdul Gani acquired occupancy right under Chotanagpur Tenancy Act, settlement purpose could not create monthly tenancy, plaintiff not entitled to khas possession.

anchor.surface_text: He also filed a written statement companytending that by operation of the provisions of Chotanagpur Tenancy Act, Abdul Gani had acquired occupancy right, that the purpose for which settlement was made with Abdul Gani companyld number create a monthly tenancy and the plaintiff was number entitled to Khas possession.

facts.text: Trial Court Additional Munsif Jamshedpur accepted defence that tenancy agricultural, Abdul Gani acquired occupancy raiyat right, governed by Chotanagpur Tenancy Act, suit not triable by civil court, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court  The Additional Munsif, Jamshedpur , accepted the defence plea that the tenancy created in favour of Abdul Gani was agricultural, that Abdul Gani had acquired an occupancy raiyats right therein and as the tenancy Act was governed by the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act the suit was number triable by a civil companyrt. Accordingly, he dismissed the suit.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge Singhbhum affirmed Trial Court findings that holding agricultural governed by Chotanagpur Tenancy Act.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Subordinate Judge, Singhbhum, with the findings of the Trial Court that the holding was agricultural and therefore governed by the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act and accordingly affirmed the judgment and decree of the Trial Court.

facts.text: Patna High Court held lease not for agricultural and horticultural purposes, no occupancy right acquired, allowed appeal, set aside lower courts decrees, decreed plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of judicature at Patna however came to the companyclusion in Second Appeal that the lease was number for agricultural and horticultural purposes and there was numberquestion. of the defendant having acquired the right of occupancy in the land. The High Court allowed the appeal, set aside the judgment and decree of the companyrts below and decreed the plaintiffs suit.

facts.text: Abdul Gani's application for lease mentions garden purpose.

anchor.surface_text: the application for lease of the land mentions garden purpose as the purpose of the tenancy, and argues that that is sufficient to make Abdul Gani a raiyat within the meaning of s. 6 of the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act.

facts.text: Application states agreement to hold land on monthly tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: after stating in the first sentence that he wanted the land for garden purpose Abdul Gani stated in the next paragraph that he agreed to hold the land on monthly tenancy

facts.text: Application states agreement to abide by house building rules.

anchor.surface_text: and again that he agreed to abide by the terms and companyditions of the Company and the house building. rules.

facts.text: Application agrees to pay security deposit and submit plan of proposed house for approval.

anchor.surface_text: I agree to pay the security deposit to be fixed by you in respect of my tenancy as soon as the plot IS allotted to me and shall submit the plan of MY proposed house for approval of the Chief Town Engineer before I start companystruction.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds terms of application show lease not for agricultural or horticultural purpose.

anchor.surface_text: The terms of the application for lease are, in our opinion, sufficient to show that the lease was number for an agricultural or horticultural purpose.

facts.text: Part of land used for growing guava trees and flowers, pacca room erected on portion.

anchor.surface_text: while a part of the land was used for growing some guava, trees and some flowers, a pacca room was also erected on a portion of the land.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that purpose of lease not agricultural or horticultural and decrees plaintiff's suit.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of all these things we find ourselves in agreement with the High Court that the purpose of the lease was number agricultural or horticultural. We have, therefore, companye to the companyclusion that the High Court was right in decreeing the plaintiffs suit.

facts.text: Calcutta and Patna High Courts decisions hold planting orchard comes within cultivation purpose.

anchor.surface_text: It has been settled by a number of decisions of the Calcutta and the Patna High Courts that the purpose of planting an orchard companyes within the purpose of cultivation.

facts.text: No document creating the lease, but Abdul Gani's application and landlord's order granting lease exist.

anchor.surface_text: While there is numberdocument creating the lease we have, in the present case, Abdul Ganis application for lease and the landlords order granting the lease.

issues.text: Whether the lease was for agricultural or horticultural purposes such that Abdul Gani became a raiyat under s. 6 of the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act and acquired occupancy right

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision of the High Court this appeal has been filed by special leave granted by this Court. In support of the appeal it is urged before us by Mr. N. Chatterjee, that the High Court erred in holding that the lease was number for agricultural or horticultural purposes. He points out that the application for lease of the land mentions garden purpose as the purpose of the tenancy, and argues that that is sufficient to make Abdul Gani a raiyat within the meaning of s. 6 of the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act.

issues.text: Whether the civil court had jurisdiction to try the suit for ejectment or whether the tenancy was exclusively governed by the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act
